lines.text: Normal? What the hell is so normal about my life? It took me eight years to become a doctor; I gave everything up to study. And for what? Anything I could get. There are no tough jobs for women doctors. I couldn't even open a decent office; I had to sweat it out in the worst hospitals. And when I finally gave myself a little time, for a little love, I wound up pickin' the wrong guy. What do ya think of that, Binnsy? Oh well. It was nice while it lasted. But for keeps he preferred his wife.
[Playfully hits Agatha]
So what's normal about that? As a matter of fact, what the hell is so normal about any one of us nuts sitting at this table?
[Points to bottle]
It's all your fault, ya mouth-opener. You know, Emma, you're the only one that still has a chance. There's a real world outside. Get out of this rat-race; go and find it.
How does it feel to be the only rooster in this hen-house?
Are you the doctor? But you're a woman!
lines.character: Mrs. Florrie Pether - Charles' pregnant wife

lines.text: Unless a lot of men have been kidding me.
Charles, it's a woman!
lines.character: Mrs. Florrie Pether - Charles' pregnant wife

lines.text: Don't worry. She'll be as good as any man.
Better!

[to Tunga Khan, Bandit Leader]
So long, ya bastard!
What you all need is a good stiff... drink.
I want you to listen carefully, Emma. I'm only trying to protect you. You understand that, don't you?
No.

You've lived a very sheltered life. Your father, both your brothers, ministers of the gospel. Dr. Cartwright comes from quite a different world. She'll never fit into a Christian community. I'm writing to... to headquarters to ask them to replace her as soon as possible.
But I find her so interesting.

Smoking? Sitting before grace? Using profane words? You call that interesting? I can see you're a young, inexperienced girl. There's something exciting about her. But morally, spiritually, she's dead.
No. Dr. Cartwright has come here to look after the sick... to take care of Mrs. Pether. She... she can't be a bad woman. She's different.
The difference is the evil in her.
